awd_titl_txt: RCN: DIMACS/Simons Collaboration on Bridging Continuous and Discrete Optimization
awd_abstract_narration:
Optimization tools and algorithms have transformed fields ranging from biology to finance, and they touch everyday lives through more efficient supply chains, better traffic management, and more secure power grids. New applications, particularly those stemming from machine learning and data science, are now challenging the field to solve larger and more complex problems on smaller devices in less time. The field is responding with innovative approaches leading to advances such as faster algorithms for maximum flow and near-real-time approximations, more efficient interior-point methods, and faster cutting-plane methods. Many of these breakthroughs bring together ideas from both continuous and discrete optimization. The DIMACS/Simons Collaboration on Bridging Continuous and Discrete Optimization aims to accelerate progress by stimulating collaboration across the many communities of optimization. The planned activities bring together computer scientists, mathematicians, operations researchers, engineers, statisticians, and algorithm developers to advance both the foundations and applications of optimization. 

The project begins with an intensive program at the Simons Institute during the fall semester of 2017 that launches the collaboration and builds momentum for activities conducted over the ensuing two years as part of the DIMACS Special Focus on Bridging Continuous and Discrete Optimization. The DIMACS special focus includes seven workshops that sustain the project through the end of 2019 and expand it to include more people and more topics. The project aims to improve the performance of optimization methods in challenging real settings with the potential to positively impact society by improving traditional applications in logistics, supply chains, engineering, infrastructure, and finance, as well as growing applications in machine learning and data science. The project will involve a large number of people in various scientific communities and expose them to new ideas, new problems, and new opportunities for collaboration. Participants will be diverse across a variety of dimensions, including women and other under-represented groups; a mix of junior and senior participants; people from multiple disciplines; and both industry and academic participants. There will also be international coordination with the Centre de Recherches Mathématiques and Polytechnique Montreal.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

por.por_cntn:
The DIMACS/Simons Collaboration on Bridging Continuous and Discrete Optimization formed a partnership between DIMACS and the Simons Institute for the Theory of Computing devoted to advancing capabilities in optimization by promoting collaborations that bridge continuous and discrete optimization. The project established a research coordination network (RCN) that featured activities at both DIMACS and the Simons Institute, bringing together computer scientists, mathematicians, operations researchers, engineers, statisticians, and algorithm developers to advance both the foundations and applications of optimization.

Activities at DIMACS and the Simons Institute enabled researchers to share information and ideas, form new collaborations, build communities across disciplines and institutions, nurture the development of early-career researchers, and contribute to the integration of research and education. This RCN project included: a large cadre of research visitors, five workshops, and several single-day symposia at the Simons Institute during the fall semester of 2017; additional research workshops held over the next several years as part of the DIMACS special focus; hosting of the annual Mixed Integer Programming Workshop (MIP); an Implementation Challenge on Vehicle Routing Problems; a Reconnect workshop aimed at professional development for faculty at colleges and universities who wish to include optimization topics in their courses and research with students; and coordination of events with two TRIPODS Institutes and the month-long program of the Centre de Recherches Mathematique on Mixed Integer Nonlinear Programming.

The project began with an intensive program on Bridging Continuous and Discrete Optimization at the Simons Institute during the fall semester of 2017, and it continued with a multi-year special focus at DIMACS that spanned the COVID-19 pandemic.

The Simons program involved 121 people who visited the Simons Institute for an extended period during the program. Of those, 39 received support through this project, while all participants benefitted from being together at the Simons Institute. The program was the first-ever jumbo program at the Simons Institute, meaning that it did not run concurrently with another program, allowing it to be roughly twice the size of a typical program. The large number of researchers brought together by the program generated intense discussion, energetic collaboration, and a host of new results and subsequent publications. The Simons program also featured many community-building activities that were especially beneficial to students and postdocs, such as reading groups, a seminar series, and industry field trips.

The DIMACS special focus began in 2018 to sustain the energy of the collaborations begun in the Simons program and expand them to include more people and more topics. The special focus is a DIMACS signature activity.  Each special focus is a multi-year program of coordinated activities addressing a broad topic, comprising activities such as workshops, research working groups, tutorials, and research visitors.

The Special Focus on Bridging Continuous and Discrete Optimization sponsored 14 events -- ten in person and four online -- and it hosted ten longer-terms visits. Special focus events involved roughly 700 participants attending in person and hundreds more attending online. The special focus events were:

1)     DIMACS Workshop on ADMM and Proximal Splitting Methods in Optimization

2)     DIMACS/TRIPODS Workshop on Optimization and Machine Learning

3)     DIMACS Workshop on Optimization in Distance Geometry

4)     DIMACS Workshop on Randomized Numerical Linear Algebra, Statistics, and Optimization

5)     CRM/DIMACS Workshop on Mixed-Integer Nonlinear Programming

6)     Mixed Integer Programming Workshop 2020 (online)

7)     Mixed Integer Programming Workshop 2021 (online)

8)     12th DIMACS Implementation Challenge Workshop: Vehicle Routing Problems (online)

9)     DIMACS Workshop on Entropy and Optimization (online)

10) Mixed Integer Programming Workshop 2022 featuring DANniversary

11) Workshop on Algorithms, Combinatorics and Optimization (ACO@CMU): Honoring the 70th Birthday of Gerard Cornuejols

12) Reconnect 2022: Optimization

13) IBM/DIMACS/DATA-INSPIRE Workshop on Bridging Game Theory and Machine Learning for Multi-party Decision Making

14) DIMACS Workshop on Computational Approaches to Vehicle Routing with a Tribute to David S. Johnson

Participants reported many important results stemming from activities of the project, several settling long-standing open questions.  Results include: the first efficient method for counting the bases of any matroid; a new NC algorithm for finding a perfect matching in planar graphs, settling the long-standing question of whether the problem is in NC; new connections between competitive analysis and interior point methods for optimization; a new general method for rounding semi-definite programs that deliver performance guarantees competitive with best-known results for several classic constraint satisfaction problems; a proof affirming a1972 conjecture that for any matroid the sequence of the number of independent sets of given sizes is ultra log-concave; a new practical algorithm for sampling from a polytope that improved theoretical bounds. Activities surrounding the Implementation Challenge illuminated the state of the art in solving classic variants of the vehicle routing problems and led to new tools and test instances. Over the course of the project, authors of more than 200 papers have told us that these works benefitted from activities of the project.


Last Modified: 12/26/2023
Modified by: Tamra J Carpenter

  • Students present in the poster session during the Mixed Integer Programming (MIP) workshop. After two years of pandemic-related delay, DIMACS hosted the annual MIP workshop as part of the Special Focus on Bridging Continuous and Discrete Optimization in May 2022.

    Poster session during the Mixed Integer Programming (MIP) workshop in 2022.
  • Suriya Gunasekar, Ben Recht, and Ludwig Schmidt enjoy some time at a whiteboard during the program on Bridging Continuous and Discrete Optimization at the Simons Institute for the Theory of Computing.
    Simons Institute for the Theory of Computing
    Copyrighted
    Tamra J Carpenter
    Suriya Gunasekar, Ben Recht, and Ludwig Schmidt at the Simons Institute.
  • Eduardo Uchoa opens the May 2023 Workshop on Computational Approaches to Vehicle Routing with a recap of results from the Implementation Challenge on Vehicle Routing Problems.
    Walter Morris
    Copyrighted
    Tamra J Carpenter
    Eduardo Uchoa opens the May 2023 Workshop on Computational Approaches to Vehicle Routing.
  • Bob Vanderbei (center) joins participants in discussions during the 2022 Reconnect workshop on optimization. Vanderbei was one of the featured lecturers.
    Tamra Carpenter
    Copyrighted
    Tamra J Carpenter
    Bob Vanderbei (center) was a speaker at the 2022 Reconnect workshop on optimization.
  • R. Tyrell Rockafellar presents at the DIMACS Workshop on ADMM and Proximal Splitting Methods in Optimization. Held in June 2018, this was the first workshop of the DIMACS Special Focus on Bridging Continuous and Discrete Optimization.
    Tamra Carpenter
    Copyrighted
    Tamra J Carpenter
    R. Tyrell Rockafellar presents at the DIMACS Workshop on ADMM and Proximal Splitting Methods in Optimization.
